here why are you in this room all of us in this room probably have use cases
that require great resiliency and scalability you need to be able to build
applications that coordinate track and audit programs with multiple steps on

us booked our own travel to Vegas I'm in that boat too so this behind-the-scenes
is a multi-step process you may have a database on a reservation site that is
updating the seed inventory with available times available seats and then
you may have initiated a search for a flight either by web mobile or SMS you
might have been selected seats provided your credit card information the system
would then have tried to confirm that the inventory was still available in the case that someone else may have selected
that exact seat and flight combination unit then confirmed your trip the system
would have finally updated the inventory to make sure that that combination was no longer available and at the end to
send out a confirmation email and hopefully guaranteed you a seat when you showed up at the airport so
how would we make this reliable scalable inaudible this would work for a handful of users how would we make this scalable
for tens of thousands hundreds of thousands of users well we could take
our logic and condense it into an application server and then we could
scale that out by having multiple application servers communicating with multiple databases but what happens if
one of those databases should happen to fail what happens if an application
server would have would happen to go down how would you know the state of your application how would you know the
state of the customers workflow in booking that flight to come to Vegas how
would you handle these challenges today in this distributed world where you have multiple nodes multiple steps and
multiple machines well that's where simple workflow comes in simple workflow
provides customers with three fundamental components to be able to handle these kinds of issues we give you
a control engine that manages your state in the cloud we're out your task and distribute the load based on this
control engine we give you HTTP api's to build your logic on top of the control
engine and then we offer a programming framework that's a higher level abstraction on top of the api's in Java
and Ruby so our customers today will
talk about their use cases there are a couple of key simple workflow concepts that I'd like to share with you so that
you can kind of relate to what they are going to present one is this concept of a decider in simple workflow a decider
is the control logic that you write for your application it's your secret sauce
it's a magic that makes your stepwise application go whether it's sequential
or parallel an activity worker are the discrete units of work that you have to
perform so if we go back to the travel booking example
the entire process would be considered your decider the transitions from step
to step and then a discrete unit of work the activity is what we call the
activity so let's talk about simple workflow customers general it may look a
lot like your companies and what you all do they're privately held venture-backed

system had a few kind of design problems it was pretty latent you know that the
content comes in the system it has to be it might be in a long queue it has to be given to two different moderators which

addition to that we acquired a new company so we have additional moderation work so anyway what we wanted to build

so we built CMS - which is moderation as a service under the covers it's one service built in Java it's a web
application and also a restful web service somebody submits content content
to it we store it off into our RDS database and then we actually begin a
workflow execution in simple workflow and simple workflow here is very important because it gives us the
ability to have a dynamic workflow execution that we can actually make decisions about which activities need to
happen next so we were able to decouple our actual moderation activity from the
system that's bringing the content in and also from the different activities that have to happen so like I said we
went to you know we have a pretty straightforward moderation kind of process our workflow is that comes in
the decider picks it up decides that the processing needs to occur after that's done proofing needs to occur optionally
and after that it's done it needs it's ready to go and we didn't pick simple workflow because we have a like a really complex
workflow we picked it because we want the ability to grow our workflow to mess with it to have experimentation to do
something different tomorrow than we did yesterday and the old system everybody knew about the state transitions of kind
of CMS one it and processing an assign so you can't touch it or wasn't proofing a sign so you know it's assigned to a moderator
for proofing so you can't touch it it's only when it's in this one magic state that you can actually make use of it and so we've been able to pull that all out
by using simple workflow and case in point when we wanted to actually our
data science team went off and did an experiment and were able to determine that with a really good level of accuracy for a certain type of
user-generated content they could predict that in fact this was going to be approved using NLP algorithms we have
seven years of training data why can't we throw NLP at this and in fact they came away with a good model and so in
order to enfold the NLP system into CMS - the change was we go to the decider
add a new if check if we haven't done NLP on this then do it we add a new activity worker which simply calls their
their their API and in couple hundred milliseconds that replies back yes in
fact this can be auto approved and we just finish the workflow or no I can't so we just continue with the workflow so
it's that kind of that kind of thing that really provides us benefit but also that gives us new abilities to innovate

is we're an API I think I want to go to the next slide weird API and essentially what we do is
we let developers write applications that find out when credit card transactions take place so if you're one

believers in AWS for all the reasons that little companies like AWS so when
we integrate with the financial systems we have to have a system that's extremely reliable which is why we've

million cards with us and they'll do one call that will take 30 million actions and so we can't of course do that

use for a for a simple workflow when we originally built the system we built that around publish and subscribe and we
essentially built the workflow ourselves and so this is how we worked we used
Jenkins Jenkins is essentially a little job scheduling system and what that did was it talked to the ELB and the ELB
talked to workers and the workers would do things like pull a giant file with 30 million transactions and run all the way
through it and stop part way through and we would never know where we could pick up and again we would not know when it
was going to be done we wouldn't know how far along it was so that wasn't really optimal and then the other thing
that we did is we do these calls from the API someone would say add this offer to 30 million people or take this off
for away from 30 million people and we would say okay got that and we could never tell you when it was done we
couldn't tell you that it happened to every buddy we can tell you that it was removed from everybody we could just have this job that ran and if it crashed
at all part way through then we would not know what was going on and we couldn't run it again what made our
system even more difficult is that we work with many many external providers through many different mechanisms and
they're not always available and so it's not that we only had to make our own systems reliable we had to make our
system work when a service we're using wasn't there we had to go back and pick up and do that work again and so our
original design using publish and subscribe probably wasn't a great design to do that and we moved to support flow
the move to simple workflow was like a
verse shattering importance to us right it's really made our day-to-day lives much much better we can run all of our
batch jobs we run them reliably we know where they are we can pick them up from the middle all those sorts of things the
other thing is that the migration was extremely easy we developed we're Ruby
on Cassandra and we developed a methodology and we just moved one workflow at a time and so we actually
were able to live in a world where we had both systems working when we just migrated one workflow developed a
library that would do that migrated another workflow and we had already sort of naturally come to the idea of workers
and deciders in our software originally and so that migration was also pretty easy we just finished migrating our last
jobs we have about 30 or 40 different workflows that run through our system to
do the integrations with our various financial providers and then to provide for the sort of bulk oriented api
operations so summary of why we did it
is that we are in a system where we must be up all the time we must be reliable we can't forget things even in a batch
operation we can't it's not good enough to get 99% them and where things fail all the time and so we needed those
abilities from simple workflow to manage the tasks understand the progress scale
the tasks and then pick up in the middle and go from there whenever something does fail so that's it
so Jeff talked about the resilience and the consolidation and easy management that simple workflow brought to card

understood it blew me away is simple workflow and it solved a really big problem that we had because we have all

at the same time for their renewals and brought our system to its needs I mean
on its back legs in the air dead as disco right and so we have one of those
job fight what I call jump that was like what we call a job finding problem meaning like my CTO is over there can I

we knew that we were kind of in trouble and the way that we were using our architecture we were doing all these

and we were kind of cheating because we didn't have to worry about compensating logic when something went wrong we just if something wrong sequel would kind of
roll it back and we knew that was no good and so we started off by using quartz net to kind of do our scheduling
of our recurring tasks and we started using Microsoft message queue and and it was okay it worked right the pie
Message Queuing was that we have these sort of dumb queues that would take
messages and we'd have to write code to move things from one queue to another and so the workflow was really in the
code that was handling the message of the queue so we couldn't reuse things of the queues were doing it was sort of a you know when you build something how
many of you engineers here you know when you build something okay you know when you build something you don't really

server accessing remote queues of different server is almost if you google Stack Overflow
you will gue --gel my name when you will see me on there posting why can't I get message to you to run on separate boxes
so we just knew it wasn't the long term solution and we had to look for something else and so we ended up
migrating to simple workflow foundation and at first we kind of I kind of simple sorry Amazon simple workflow and at
first I sort of eat it with hesitant what is this how does this work there wasn't really a dotnet API for it and we
ended up diving into it and within about a week after a proof-of-concept we knew that this was the solution we ended up
modeling everything we did as a workflow getting rid of queues all together and one of the great things about it was
that it really forced us to design well so it forced us to think about our order process and cut them up into manageable
chunks so for us when you process in order you have to write it to the database and you have to go and check though make sure the credit card is
valid then you have to go and write all the invoice and payment records to the database and you have to go and fulfill it that might mean creating a membership
it might mean expend extending a membership date might mean registering for you event you for an event it might mean subscribing you to something
whatever or might be all those things then we have to go and actually capture the credit card then we have to go and
send email as a confirmation and it forced us to kind of break our logic up into sort of manageable chunks and when
we did that we realized wow we can write compensating logic too and we can think really hard about how to back out of
certain situations depending if there's a failure so for instance if what do we do if the credit card fails easy right
well what do we do if something is wrong and the credit card processor is unavailable or what do we if there's a database lag or a timeout
we could actually compensate for that and retry we could actually say you know what if there's a problem with the database or it's not available
wait a minute try again we could never do anything like that when we were running these big transactions so what
we got was sort of still a scalability and reliability and if you see now the
way our conjecture looks is when you run a process in our system you're actually just making a call to our API which is
kicking off the workflow and then we have our job execution services have migrated from these sort of ugly evil
quartz dotnet sort of you know Windows service you know stop in the middle of

really was just icing on the cake for us is we got for free distributed
processing so it might turn out that different parts of the same workflow run on different servers and that's okay
